thread.title: De Silvestro applies for licence dispensation
thread.title_full: De Silvestro applies for licence dispensation

title: De Silvestro applies for licence dispensation
text:
Supercars: Simona De Silvestro applies for CAMS Superlicence dispensation Will Dale, FOX SPORTS February 20, 2017 2:45pm 
HIGH profile Supercars rookie Simona De Silvestro has applied for special dispensation as she doesn’t automatically qualify for a CAMS Superlicence. 
The Swiss racer makes her fulltime debut in the championship with Nissan Motorsport this year, the first of a three-year deal orchestrated by Supercars to secure a female driver for its grid. 
This year also marks the first season that all Supercars drivers will need to hold a CAMS Superlicence, introduced to prevent inexperienced drivers from graduating to the championship too quickly. 
ANALYSIS: The biggest hurdle De Silvestro faces in adapting to Supercars 
Eligibility for a Superlicence falls under three criteria: a) be over 17 years of age b) in possession of an FIA International Circuit C Racing licence, and c) satisfy one of the following: — compete in a minimum of three VASC rounds in the last five years, — hold a minimum of a Gold FIA Driver Categorisation, or — rack up a minimum of 13 CAMS or FIA Superlicence points in the past five years. 
De Silvestro ticks a) and b) , but not c) . Having not raced in GT cars her name doesn’t appear on the FIA’s driver seeding list, and she has only raced in two VASC events previously. 
While she notched up podium and top-five finishes across the past five years in the IndyCar Series and FIA Formula E, her overall championship finishes are not enough to earn her any FIA Superlicence points. 
However, it is expected that an exemption will be forthcoming. 
Foxsports.com.au understands that De Silvestro will likely receive a dispensation from CAMS based on her international record, with cases such as De Silvestro’s the reason that the dispensation option exists. 
The qualification criteria for a CAMS Superlicence has already caused controversy this year, with both of Lucas Dumbrell Motorsport’s intended drivers for 2017 applying for a dispensation.
